titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Mr Ducornau called on me this forenoon, and informed me that he and Mr Hall should be ready to go next Thursday— We had been invited to attend the performance of the funeral service for Admiral Bentinck, at the English Church at 6 O’Clock in the afternoon. Having attended the same service there several times before, and always found that they began an hour later than the time fixed, I thought it would be time enough at 7 this Evening, and went at that hour— The service was just finished at the moment when we arrived, which gave me a new lesson of punctuality. I went nevertheless into the vestry, where I found the Officers of the English Embassy, and some other persons; with Drs: Pitt and Beresford— I mentioned to Dr Pitt the cause of my having arrived late; he said they had been obliged to begin earlier than usual, because the Duke of Oldenburg had attended, and had come very punctually at the hour appointed— He apologized to me for not having sent me the certificate which I had asked him some Months since— I asked Dr: Beresford, what was the rule of the Greek Church for determining the time of Easter— He did not know— The Abbé Lavoisier the other day was unable to answer me the same question— Sir Francis d’Ivernois stop’d me to ask me again about my Silesian Letters— He said he had enquired at the Booksellers, and could not procure them. I asked him to accept a copy of the french translation of them, which I promised to send him— We returned from the church directly home— Mr Lewis and Mr Slade soon afterwards came in and stayed to tea— Charles passed the Evening at Countess Colombi’s where there was a large party of children.

2. Rose at five this morning, and wrote Notes to Count Romanzoff and Count Löwenhielm requesting Passports for Mr Ducorneau, and Mr: Hall. Also to Sir Francis D’Ivernois, to whom I sent the translation of my Silesian Letters— Mr Plummer paid me a long morning visit, and mentioned to me his intention of returning to America— He purposes to go in about three weeks, and Mr Proud intends to go with him— I promised to charge him with dispatches, and to ask, Courier’s Passports for him— The remainder of the day I was engaged in writing for Mr Ducornau; but lost the greatest part of the Evening, by the same cause which has so often produced the like effect; an overpowering drowsiness. I made a very short Evening; after reading a few pages in Voltaire’s Essai sur les Moeurs Vol. 3.

3. Rose soon after day’light and walked an hour and a half before breakfast.— Sir Francis D’Ivernois paid me a long visit, and in return for my Silesian Letters gave me two of his own publications— Les trois Offrandes—and Napoleon Administrateur et Financier— He found Mr Harris with me, and we had a long conversation together, upon political affairs— He has all the prejudices, and all the passions of an English Ministerialist, which was to be expected; but he very stoutly contends that the British Ministers deplore the War with America— Mr Harris mentioned to him Sir Robert Wilson’s assertion at Dr: Creighton’s table, that Mr Perceval had told him a very few days before his death that he was determined upon a War with America— Sir Francis said he did not believe that Mr Perceval had ever said any such thing to Sir Robert Wilson—that Mr Perceval was the only member of the British Cabinet, deeply, strongly, inflexibly attached to the Orders in Council; that he probably would not have abandoned them to prevent a War with America— But he did not believe they would produce a War— Sir Francis said that he had been very intimately acquainted with Mr Perceval, who had been with him, and left him not five minutes before he was murdered. That he had often conversed with him on the subject of America— That Mr Perceval always expressed himself averse to a War, with America—but he did not believe it would come to a War— Sir Francis appeared to hope that the War between America and England would yet be short— He founded his hopes on the expectation that the War would become too unpopular in America to be pursued— On this point as on almost every other I found his opinions at the greatest possible variance from mine— As to the question of impressment he said he did not see how that could be settled unless all the sailors in the British Navy would submit to be tattooed, with a G.R. in indian ink upon the arm— But he doubted whether they would consent to that— This is the strangest expedient that I believe was ever devised— But he mentioned it seriously— We talked about the American Revolution, the War against which he thought had been excessively impolitic in Britain— But as to the Justice of the case he had his doubts— But he said he was one of the small number of persons who believed the loss of the American Colonies to have been the Origin of the king of England’s Malady— As Sir Francis is under personal obligations to the king of England I did not think it suitable to tell him what I thought—that he had mistaken the Cause for the effect.— I made a short Evening again—longer however than the last.

4. Rose at 5. which is yet an hour before daylight— Walked only before breakfast— Mr Ducorneau and Mr Hall called upon me; I gave them their passports and the packets that I had ready; they are to call again however before they go, to-morrow morning. Mr Harris also paid me a long Morning visit— He told me that his commercial partnership with Meyer and Brüxner, would terminate on the 31st: of March—that he was winding up all his affairs here, and that his present intention was to go next Summer to America— This Evening I finished reading the third Volume of Dutens’s Memoirs, and read one or two Chapters in Voltaire— Great part of the Morning had been employed in reading English Newspapers which Mr Harris sent me to the 5th: of February.

5. Rose after day light, and walked before Breakfast— Mr Ducorneau came in his Kibitka, and stopp’d on his way, and took my last packet with one from Count Löwenhielm to Count Engeström, the Swedish Minister of foreign Affairs— I went with Charles to see the Puppet-shows, or Gachellies on the river.— They are exhibited during the Butter week, or Carnaval, from last Wednesday untill next Sunday— The Court mourning is suspended these five days; of which I received a Notification from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies, Narishkin— We saw two, of the five Shows upon the river; and they are the same we had seen last year, both at Easter, and at the Carnaval— In the Evening, Charles read to me in Berquin’s livre de famille. I read two or three Chapters of Voltaire, and closed the Evening soon after 9 O’Clock.

6. Read about an hour by Candle-light this morning, and walked before Breakfast. I went with Charles upon the river, and saw two more of the puppet-show Exhibitions, in one of which only there was a new performer, who balanced a ladder with a boy mounted upon it; a scale of five or six large wheels, and a knot of three heavy hangers, by the point of the central one, upon his chin, nose and forehead. This young Hercules was the only personage, I had never seen before— Mr Krehmer paid the ladies an Evening visit, and invited us all to dine at Ochta to-morrow. I read the translated extract from the Edinburgh Review, on the French Code of Conscription; said to have been written by Mr Walsh.— This is a part of the Trois Offrandes published by Sir Francis D’Ivernois— It is certainly a Code of rigorous servitude; and bears so heavily upon the French Nation, that it is doubtful whether it can for any great length of time be maintained— But it is the essence of the French power, and if it fails, France will find it difficult to maintain any of her Conquests, if not even her antient limits.

7. Rose before 5 and passed the time in laborious study untill 9 when we breakfasted— Read prayers for Quadragesima Sunday, or the first Sunday in Lent, and Sterne’s Sermon, upon the Parable of the rich man and Lazarus—a Charity Sermon. The text does not seem much adapted to the doctrine; but almost all these discourses are desultory— I walked about an hour before dinner— The crowd of People at the Ice-hills, and puppet-shows on the river, and in the procession of sleighs and Carriages round the Corner of the Winter-Palace, was greater than I had ever seen it before— The whole family went out with me to Ochta and dined at Mr Krehmer’s— The company was not numerous—about
twenty persons, among whom was Baron Budberg brother of a former Minister of foreign Affairs, and who was himself appointed before the War Minister to Naples; and Captain Forbes, one of Lord Cathcart’s Aid de Camp’s— After dinner Baron Campenhausen who resides in the neighbourhood of Mr Krehmer came in— They had Cards, and Music. We came home about eleven in the Evening— I read a few pages in Cicero de Natura Deorum, and wrote part of a Letter to George—

8. Had a long morning visit from Mr: Montreal— Rode in the Sleigh with Charles and walked home— Visits also from Mr Fisher and Mr Gibson in the Morning, and from Mr Lewis in the Evening.— Finished my letter to George— Rose this Morning before six O’Clock and with the dawn. Charles read to me several scenes in one of Berquin’s dramas, and then I joined in his Amusement.

9. Miss Frederica, and Miss Clementine de Bode, Countess Colombi’s two Sister’s dined with us, and spent the Evening with the Ladies— I walked the round of five miles before breakfast alone; and that of three with Charles before dinner— Wrote something in a political dissertation which I have commenced without any determinate plan what to make of it in the end; but which most probably will end in Nothing— I read two or three Chapters of Voltaire in the Evening; but rising so early as I now usually do, and taking so much exercise, I find it excessively irksome to study at-all after dinner, and cannot command attention enough to read with any profit.

10. Rose by Candle light, about 5—and walked untill 1/4 past 7. The Sun rises at 1/2 past 6.— After Breakfast I went with Charles in the Sleigh to the village opposite Chrestoffsky and Yelagin islands, where several companies of Bashkirs are quartered.— These are a sort of Calmuck Savages, who are employed in the Russian armies, and whose weapons are the bow and arrow— We saw a number of them in the Street of the Village; one of whom, a young man, was amusing himself with his bow and arrow— We met Mr Willing and Mr Tilden, going out also for the purpose of seeing them— The young Bashkir shot his arrow at a distance of about two hundred yards with considerable accuracy— But he did not appear accustomed to shoot at a small and distant mark, as is usual among the North American Indians— His arrows were generally tipp’d with a small triangular iron blade, like the broken blade of a sharp pointed table knife— Others had a head of horn in a conical form— There was nothing very peculiar in their dress— They are expecting their Commander, and are then to perform manoeuvres— On returning home I called at Sir Francis D’Ivernois’s lodgings; but found he had left the City on Sunday— After dinner I walked, the first time this Season—took the round by the lower Admiralty— The rest of the Evening I spent in hearing Charles read, and in playing with him— Read with difficulty one Chapter of Voltaire. Mrs Adams was taken ill again this morning and confined the whole day to her bed.

11. I took Charles with me this morning before Breakfast and we walked round by the marble Palace— Before dinner we rode out in the sleigh to Krasna Kabak which with the return is about a twelve Miles ride— He afterwards rode again with his Aunt. After dinner I walked alone; and then heard Charles read in Berquin— Mrs Adams was confined the whole day to her bed.— I wrote a little and read several Chapters of Voltaire—

12. Morning walk without Charles the Thermometer being at -13. Rode round the City with him before dinner in the Sleigh, and walked with him after dinner— Began giving him lessons of Arithmetick in the Morning, and heard him in Berquin in the Evening— When I devote so much of the day to him, I have very little time left for any thing else— Wrote very little— Read a few Chapters of Voltaire, and part of Ernesti’s Dedication to his first Edition of Cicero—

13. The Clear and cold weather continues— I rose at five, and walked before Breakfast— Rode with Charles in the Sleigh to Kammenoi-Ostrof and in returning stop’d at Mr Raimbert’s— His attack of the Palsy has not hitherto been followed by a second, and he has partly recovered the use of his left arm and leg— But his Hopes of Recovery have nearly vanished, and his Spirits are proportionably dejected. He is unhappy too in his situation here, owing to the War, and intends to quit the Country next Summer— Mr Montreal was not at home— After dinner I walked an hour with Charles, and finished reading the third Volume of Voltaire’s Essai sur les Moeurs— The Papal Usurpations and Encroachments, and the Crusades are the theme of this Volume, which is not so obscene, nor so irreligious as the first and second, though still in both respects very exceptionable— I read also the remainder of Ernesti’s Dedication, and his Prefaces— They are written in Latin worthy of Cicero himself; and the Dedication is the best dissertation on the proper method of studying the antient Classicks that I have seen. I am sorry I did not read it twenty years ago— Even now I discover that one sheet of it is missing from my Copy of the Book. It is addressed to a Magistrate of Leipsick named Stigliz, of whom I never heard before, but to whose name it is a monument of the most honourable kind— This occupation however absorbed so much of the day, that I wrote only a few lines— Mr Redwood paid us an Evening visit.

14. Rose by Candle-light at five— Walked alone before Breakfast, and with Charles after dinner— Read prayers for the second Sunday in lent; and Sterne’s Sermon against Pride— It differs from the generality of his discourses, not being taken from any parable or particular Story— The
text is a precept of Christ, and the Sermon is a comment upon it—more argumentative than he usually is, but with his touches both of feeling and of humour— There must have been something singularly hysterical in Sterne’s Genius, for it is in a perpetual effort to excite almost at the same moment laughter and tears— He shews what is indeed not difficult the folly and impolicy of Pride, but he seems inclined to relax from the rigour of his principles in favour of Beauty; which looks as if he was willing to flatter the Passions of the women even in the Pulpit— I wrote part of a letter to George, and read the remainder of Cicero de Natura Deorum Book 1. in Olivet’s Translation— Also some years of Fabricius’s Life of Cicero, arranged in the form of Annals— The life of Cicero, is one of the best exhortations to indefatigable Industry; but I need a more powerful Monitor even than Cicero.

15. Rose about five O’Clock, but it was already day-light— At six I waked Charles, and walked with him before Breakfast— Walked again with him after dinner— In the interval, although I did not leave my chamber the time wore away, so that I did not finish the letter yesterday commenced— I read in Fabricius’s Life of Cicero; with part of Olivet’s Appendix to his Translation of the first Book of Cicero de Natura Deorum— Another and a mere trifling way in which I consume several hours is in making indexes to my Volumes of American State Papers.— My former Servant Pietro Irosilly, who left my service, about two months since, and went to the hospital, died there yesterday, a victim to his vices— This day four months ago he was married to a very pretty and apparently innocent girl— In what Stations of life, are the lessons of Temperance not written in the fate of those who disregard them?

16. Charles walked with me again morning and Evening; although the weather has changed, moderated and become foul— It snowed great part of this day— I went to Mr Meyer’s on business; where I heard of the Alliance concluded between the king of Prussia, and the Emperor Alexander, which I did not believe, but which was confirmed by Mr Harris who paid us a visit in the Evening— Also the taking of Berlin by the Russians— There are also Accounts from England to 16 Feby: and from America to 17. January— And Mr Harris says Mr Madison’s re-election is ascertained— I had likewise this Morning, a long visit from the General of the Jesuits, who came to enquire if I had any late letters from America, and to ask me to forward some from him to his associates there— I made enquiries of him concerning the Instruction in their College here; and was surprized to find that they do not teach Greek— He says they formerly did— But the modern languages and mathematics, with the example of the German Universities, have absolutely expelled Greek from their Classes.— I likewise asked him by what rule the Russian Greek Church fixed their time of Easter— He did not know that they had a different Rule from that fixed at the Council of Nicaea; untill I shewed him by the Almanach for this year that they do not observe it— He thought the only difference was of the Old and New Style— But that is not all— Easter this Year is celebrated here the second, instead of the first Sunday after the full moon, following the 21st: of March— He promised me however to enquire and let me know hereafter what rule they do follow— He told me that the Emperor Paul had the project of introducing the New Style here; but the Metropolitan objected that it would require a total alteration in the rubrick of their Church Books; and make all the Books now in use of no service— The expence of printing new ones deterred Paul from the Execution of his design. I wrote scarcely any thing this day— Read a few pages of Fabricius, and Olivet’s Remarks on the Theology of the Greek Philosophers—with which I was much gratified.

17. Every change of the weather in this Country, affects my own health considerably, and that of my family much more. I had an entirely sleepless Night— Rose between 5 and 6— And at 7 I took Charles out with me to walk— But he has taken a bad Cold and was quite unwell, great part of the day— From Breakfast time I did not go out again— It snowed and rained at the hours when I usually walked— Mr Redwood called upon me twice to ask me to see Mr Gourieff the Minister of Finance, and sollicit him in Redwood’s behalf— He brought here last Summer some Straw Hats, which being prohibited, have been confiscated, and now they come upon him for the fine— I promised to see Mr Gourieff, and sent to ask him for an interview to-morrow— He appointed eleven O’Clock in the morning for that purpose— I sent for my Landlord Mr Strugofshchikoff and paid him a half-year’s Rent in Advance— He conversed with me, as he always does upon politics and upon the character of the Russian People— He is very well satisfied with the present state and prospect of Affairs; and thinks the Emperor Alexander might now come home and take his ease. He says that of the Petersburg levy of men last Summer, of one Man in ten, the greatest part have perished, and the rest have been or will be incorporated in the regiments— Not one of them will ever come back. He spoke of their lent, of which this is the second week— They keep the first and last weeks with great rigour, and in them they are not allowed to eat fish— No animal food of any kind—scarcely any-thing but bread, Oil, and mushrooms, dry— The common people, he says, consider a violation of the lent, as the most heinous of Crimes— Murder they suppose may be pardoned, but to break the fast is a Sin utterly irremissible— He himself kept the fast last week; not from a religious scruple, but because he thought it a salubrious practice, and an useful one, to form habits of self-denial— I am of that opinion myself, and I have often wished that the reformers who settled New-England had not abolished the practice of fasting in lent— I am convinced that occasional fasting, & particularly abstinence from animal food, for several weeks at a time and every year, is wholesome both to body and mind— It is true that fasting is not expressly enjoined in the Scriptures, and therefore cannot be required as a religious observance; but unless prescribed by a principle of religion there is no
motive sufficient powerful to controul the appetites of men.— I finished reading the Appendix to the first Volume of Olivet’s translation of Cicero de Natura Deorum—

18. Rose by Candle-light; and of course before 5 O’Clock— Walked alone, Charles being yet unwell— At 11. O’Clock I called upon Mr Gourieff to sollicit him in behalf of Mr Redwood— He said that with regard to the Confiscation of the goods, it was impossible to revoke that, but with respect to the fine, if I would write him a Note, he would lay it before the Committee of Ministers, and endeavour to obtain its remission. He had no discretion to remit the fine— If the Emperor were here, he should lay the application before His Majesty— He should now refer it to the Committee of Ministers, and would use his endeavours to have its request complied with— I wrote and sent him the Note this Evening— I paid a visit to Mr Laval, and had a long Conversation with him— After returning home I rode out with Mrs Adams and Charles to the Village, where the Bashkirs are quartered; and where we saw a number of them— Miss Frederica, and Miss Clementine de Bode dined with us, and were here part of the Evening. I read two Chapters in Voltaire’s Essai Vol. 4:

19. After another night almost entirely sleepless I rose between 5 and 6. O’Clock— This loss of sleep, which so often happens to me, and for which I have found no effectual remedy contributes more than any thing to break that constant regularity of hours which I have so long desired to establish as one of my rules of life— After a sleepless Night I feel a depression and dispersion of animal Spirits which excessively weakens the capacity of attention in my Mind; I lose of course great part of the succeeding day, and afterwards when I obtain a Night of sleep; it generally continues beyond the proper rising hour and intrenches upon the succeeding day.— I walked this morning an hour with Charles— Mr Redwood called upon me, and I informed him of the application I made yesterday in his favour to Mr Gourieff— Mr Plummer, and Mr Proud also came to enquire if I could put in a third name into a Courier’s Passport for Mr Gair; and to inform me that they expected to be ready to go next Monday week. I dined at Count Romanzoff’s with a Company of about 35 persons.— There were five Ladies—a Princess Galitzin, Countess Orloff, the richest heiress in Russia, Madame Kosodavleff, Madame Wassiltchikoff, and another Lady— Several of the Gentlemen came very late; and Captain Guedes, after the company were seated at table. I sat next to him and to Count Maistre with whom I had at table much conversation, chiefly upon literature and the Bible—Plutarch and Plato—St Paul and Herodotus—Racine and Malthus and Paley. I came home between 6 and 7. but could not read; and scarcely could hear Charles read part of one of Miss Edgworth’s tales— At 9 I went to bed.

20. Rose at 7 O’Clock, untill which time I slept— Walked before Breakfast— Count Maistre sent me the latest English Newspapers to 12 Feby: and from breakfast untill nearly dinnertime I was employed in reading them— Mr Treadwell called upon me, an American lately arrived from Moscow— Received a Notification for a Te Deum to morrow Morning 11 O’Clock, at the Cazan Church. I walked again after dinner— The Ladies and Charles went and passed the Evening at Countess Colombi’s— I found it impracticable to read in the Evening and betook myself again to bed at 9. It is a singular and painful Constitution of Body that when up I cannot keep myself awake; and in bed cannot sleep.

21. I awaked before three this morning, and rose by Candle light about four— The morning was remarkably fine, and I took a long walk before Breakfast to see the Sun rise on the day of the vernal Equinox.— Between 11 and 12 went with Mr Smith to the Cazan Church—we arrived after the Mass had begun, and this day the foreign Ministers had been placed to attend at the Mass before the Te Deum— So we were late— The two Ceremonies lasted nearly three hours— After returning home I read prayers for the third Sunday in lent, and Sterne’s Sermon upon humility— It is a second part of that upon Pride, and in point of argument is substantially the same. Reasoning in favour of humility, is of course reasoning against Pride; and vice versa. This discourse however concludes with ridicule and invective against Quakers and Methodists, whose special motions of the Spirit, and experiences it attributes to spiritual Pride— Sermons against Sectaries never reclaim them— They may perhaps guard others from falling into their delusions— I also read part of Olivet’s second Dialogue de Natura Deorum; setting forth the theology of the Stoics. Their Gods and their Astronomy are about equally wide from the Truth— There is a strange mixture of good and bad reasoning in their Doctrines. They inferred intelligent causes from the visible order of the universe.— This argument is so irresistible that it can never be encountered but by folly or absurdity— But instead of inferring one Universal intelligent cause the Creator of all things, the Stoics inferred distinct intelligent Causes for the order of each mass of Matter— Thus in their idea the Earth was a God—the Sun, Moon, Planets and fixed Stars were all Gods—and with these Gods they very naturally admitted others innumerable— I walked again after dinner; and finding myself unable to read in the Evening went to bed at 9. Charles was quite unwell—and omitted reading—the first time for four Months.

22. Mrs Adams and Charles were both ill in the Night; and I was obliged to get up— Having again fallen asleep I rose this Morning not untill seven— Walked before breakfast— Mr Fisher called upon me, with Mr Rogers lately arrived from Moscow and Archangel.— Mr Fisher brought me the Emperor Paul’s two Ukazes on the coinage. Walk again after dinner— Mr Lewis spent the Evening with us— We had also a visit from Captain Forbes
one of Lord Cathcart’s Aids, and attached to the English Embassy.— The General of the Jesuits likewise paid me a morning visit, and brought me a letter to be forwarded to America— He had also a Statement by one of the fathers of his College, explaining the reason why the festival of Easter falls out on different days this year, in the Greek and Roman Calendars— It is not owing to the difference of the Solar year; but from that of the Epact.— That of the New Style is XXVIII. that of the Old Style IX. that is— According to the Gregorian Calendar the Solar year in its Embolysmic revolution of 19 years exceeds the lunar year by 28 days— According to the Julian Calendar this same year in its embolysmic revolution of 19 years exceeds the lunar year only by 9 days— Hence by the first the term of Easter is 15 April which being the 5th Holiday of Passion-week Easter is transferred to the next Sunday, being 18 April.— By the second the Pascal term is 7/19 April, which being the second Holiday, Easter is transferred to the next Sunday 13/25 April— The term of Easter does not therefore depend solely upon the time of the full moon succeeding 21. March, but also upon the comparative state of the Solar and Lunar Years, by the two Calendars— The Reverend Father told me that the Russian Priests knew nothing about the cause of the difference— That one of his Associates had enquired of them at Riga, at Moscow and here— Nobody could tell him— This explanation itself leaves other questions to be solved—particularly why and how the difference of Epact, should operate upon the calculation of the full moon— Count Maistre lent me Paley’s Evidences of Christianity; part of the first Volume of which I read— I also heard Charles read in Berquin, early in the Evening.

23. Rose between 5 and 6 and walked alone before Breakfast. Second walk after dinner to the Baths, and I took a warm Bath— The weather continues fine— In the day time quite warm, with the Sun, but freezing every Night. I read part of Paley’s Evidences of Christianity—Vol 1.— In Charles’s Morning lessons, I am endeavouring to teach him the first rudiments of Arithmetic— His infirm state of health, particularly the almost incessant Colds in the head, with which he is afflicted compel me to abridge his lessons, and to make his studies very light— I had in a great measure taught George to read; so that the difficulties of instruction to Charles in that point were not new— But I had never attempted Arithmetic with George, and I find obstacles to the communication of intelligence with regard to numbers, that were unexpected— I have yet been unable to make Charles comprehend the very first idea of addition—and he as yet very imperfectly comprehends even that of Numeration— My stock of Patience needs much recruiting, and much self-admonition to make me pursue this object with suitable perseverance. [symbols]

24. Walks before breakfast, and after dinner, alone— Charles has a Catarrh very similar to that which alarmed us so much precisely at this time last year. I am therefore deterred from taking him out to walk with me— I devoted most of the day to writing letters— The two Miss Bode’s dined and spent the Evening with us— Mr Harris also paid us an Evening visit— There was an illumination of the Streets, it being the anniversary of the Emperor’s accession to the Throne— But no other public notice of the day— The Ladies entertained us with music— I attempted to read a little in the Evening, but found it useless— I was kept up however untill 11; and Charles kept me awake with his cough, nearly two hours longer.

25. A Captain Holliday, Master of one of the American Vessels at Cronstadt came to ask my opinion and advice— The Russian Government are taking up transports, to carry provisions for their armies to the Prussian Ports; and his enquiry was whether I thought American Vessels would be safe from capture by the English, while employed in that service; either under their own flag, or by a nominal sale of the ship to obtain a Russian flag— I told him I thought that in either case their safety would be precarious— The service would be such as it could not be supposed the British would be very eager to defeat or obstruct—but it would depend upon the temper and discretion of the Commander of every British vessel they might meet— He said he expected the Russian Government would Charter them by the Month— I told him the English might possibly let them pass while actually upon the Service; but the moment that was finished they would take every vessel they could catch— Mr Redwood likewise came to enquire If I had received an Answer from Mr Gourieff, to the application I had made in his behalf— I had not— At 6 this Evening I attended by invitation at the English Church the funeral of a Mrs Booker, a relation of Dr: Simpson’s— The English people residing here were generally present— I walked afterwards about an hour— I finished reading the first Volume of Paley on the Evidences of Christianity, and began the second— But interesting as this Book is I cannot command attention to read in the Evening— Neither will my eyes allow me to read much by Candle-light— Nine is my hour for Bed.

26. Charles walked with me this morning. Mr Willing with Mr Tilden, and afterwards Mr Harris paid me morning visits— From an excess of punctuality I prepared Notes to Count Romanzoff and Count Löwenhielm, asking Courier’s Passports for Mr Plummer and Mr Proud: to go next Monday, through Finland to Gothenburg. I intended to have sent the Notes to-morrow Morning— But Mr Plummer sent me word this day, by Mr Smith that they had changed their plan, and now intend to go, not untill the end of the next week, and by the way of Liebau— I walked again after dinner, alone—and then read an hour in Paley’s Evidences. Vol 2. The weather continues clear and mild.

27. Took Charles again with me to walk this morning before breakfast— I attended afterwards a sale of Books which began this day— It was attended by all the Booksellers, and the Books that were good for any thing sold at excessive high prices— The War probably raises the value of good french Books— After I returned home Mr Booker called upon me— He was formerly the ship Broker at Cronstadt, both for English and American Vessels— When the War between Russia and England began he went to England— Mr Sparrow who had been a Clerk in his house
was made the Agent for American vessels, by Mr Harris— Mr Booker having now returned from England, appears desirous to have the whole of his former agencies restored to him— But as to American Vessels, while our War with England lasts, there will be none here to need an agent— I walked again after dinner— The Ladies and Charles rode out— I finished reading Paley’s Evidences of Christianity, a book from which I have derived some information, and some confirmation to my faith— His argument is strong, ingenious, and convincing. His style, clear and lively, though always temperate— He establishes the Evidence of Christ’s Miracles upon an immoveable basis— He adduces the testimony of Clemens Romanus, Hermas, Polycarp, and Ignatius, and the succession of Christian writers during the three first centuries of Christianity, in a manner which ought not to have been, but which was new to me— This part of his works is avowedly a mere abridgment from Lardner’s Credibility of the Gospel History— A Book which I possess in America, but never read— Paley’s principal object is to refute Hume’s Essay upon Miracles; which he does much to my satisfaction. He contests very successfully Hume’s first principle; that no Evidence can be sufficient to obtain the belief of a miracle— He discriminates between the three instances of Miracles mentioned by Hume, as the best authenticated in history, and those of Christ and his Apostles, with great sagacity, and demonstrates that any comparison between them is absurd. He is equally powerful in proving that a parallel between the progress of Mahometanism and that of Christianity is utterly fallacious. The Part of Dr Paley’s Book with which I am least satisfied is precisely that which I was most curious to read—the Chapter on the Morality of the Gospel— He adopts without Qualification the whole of Soame Jenyns’s internal Evidence of Christianity; which Dr: M’Laine of the Hague strongly objected against— I think he does not estimate its value the peculiar merit of the gospel morality— He strongly intimates and perhaps formally admits that the Christian Morality is not applicable to men in the public relations of Nations— In the excess of Candour he concedes too much to the adversary. The laxity of his Moral Philosophy, which has been justly censured by Dr Gisborne infects even that part of this Book— Perhaps this sort of composition with the World may be the means of retaining within the Christian fold many who by adherence to a more rigorous discipline might be driven from it— But it does not accord with my ideas of the truth— Peace on Earth, good will to Men; it seems to me was as essential a part of Christ’s Mission, as the promise of a future life.

28. Morning and Evening walks— I read prayers for the fourth Sunday in Lent and Sterne’s Sermons upon the Advantages of Christianity to the World—from the text Professing themselves to be wise they became fools. (Rom. 1.22.) There is not much connection between the Doctrine and the text— The style is temperate, and the remarks are judicious, but the subject is treated some what superficially.— I wrote part of a letter to George, and in the Evening read a few pages of Cicero de Natura Deorum— Charles however came and interrupted me, and read to me a story in Berquin.

29. After ten days of as fine weather as I ever witnessed in any Country, and those precisely at and immediately succeeding the vernal equinox it changed and clouded up this day. I walked however before morning and after dinner—alone— In the forenoon I attended the sale of Books and made a few purchases— Wrote a little, and after my Evening walk finished the second of Cicero’s Dialogues de Natura Deorum— Containing the exposition of the Stoic Doctrine by Balbus— It is strange to observe how justly and strongly the Stoics laid down their premises, and how absurdly they drew their Conclusions— In the first Chapter of St: Paul’s Epistle to the Romans, says The invisible things of God from the creation of the world, are clearly seen, being understood, by the things that are made; even his eternal power and Godhead— This argument from the visible Creation, and its order is precisely that upon which Balbus dwells; he insists upon it with such earnestness, and spreads out the proof into such minute detail that Cotta in his reply makes the very anxiety with which he hangs upon it an evidence that the point was not so clear and obvious as he had asserted it to be— Why so eager to multiply proofs, says he, of what you assert to be self-evident. And this is all the reply attempted by Cotta, to that part of the argument— But the error of the Stoics was, in considering the intelligence displayed in the physical Government of the World, as residing in the material world itself— They never conceived the idea of God as a Creator, nor his omnipotence, nor his Unity— Balbus’s Syllogism is “That which is endued with reason, is better than that which is not[”]— But there is nothing better than the World— Therefore the World is endued with Reason. This notable process he takes from Zeno, the founder of the sect, who proved by the same middle term that the World (meaning the Earth) was wise, was happy, was eternal, and in fine was God—or rather a God— For on the same principle he takes each of the planets and fixed Stars to be a God; besides innumerable others— Cotta ridicules these Syllogisms as they deserve, and assigns certainly a better reason for his belief of the Gods—the authority of their Ancestors— Because they were of the religious Establishment. Because he had been taught to believe and worship them— Because he was a man of rank and reputation, and moreover an Augur—which Balbus in closing
his discourse had desired him not to forget. It seems to me one of the strongest indications of the weakness of the human understanding that the Stoics after inferring an intelligent principle from the order of the universe, should not have perceived at least the unity of that principle, or have discovered that from a multitude of distinct and independent intelligences disorder and confusion must result as necessarily as from no intelligent principle at-all— St. Paul accounts for it, and it is on this very topic that he says, professing themselves wise, they became fools.

30. Charles had a disturbed and restless Night— He is scarcely ever free from a sort of Catarrhal cough in the Night, and has now the further weakness arising from rapid growth— I walked alone before Breakfast, and after it attended the sale of Books—purchased two or three small Articles— After dinner I went out to take my Evening walk, but was immediately turned back by the Rain— Charles passed the whole Evening in my Chamber and prevented me from reading— He read to me part of a story from Berquin, and amused himself the rest of the time with St: Quentin’s Counters— I met Captain Guedes at the sale, and invited him to dine with us on Thursday.— Mrs: Adams was unwell.

31. Walked before Breakfast, and in the forenoon called at Reynaud’s shop and settled an Account there, for which I had made myself responsible— Made up others of my Accounts, it being the orderly quarter-day for my public account— I did not attend the sale of Books, nor walk after dinner, the weather being bad, and the streets scarcely passable. Charles occupied me the whole Evening, partly reading in Berquin, and partly at play— I had morning Visits from Mr Montreal and Mr Harris—

Day. I rise between 5 and 6 in the morning— Not once I believe in the course of the present month so late as 7— But the frequency with which I lose the greatest part of the Night, and sometimes the whole, unable to sleep, with the lassitude which always afflicts me the ensuing day and Night has hitherto disabled me from effecting my intention of rising regularly at 5.— I begin the day with reading five Chapters of the German Bible— Walk an hour and a half— Read or write the rest of the time untill 9. which is now our Breakfasting hour— After this I hear Charles read two, and now three Chapters in the English New Testament.— Then give him a short lesson of Arithmetic, in which I have not yet been able to make him comprehend even the first principle of Addition, though he has the Multiplication table by heart, and is learning it in French— He is just beginning to understand decimal numeration, and can read cyphered numbers to the amount of hundreds of Millions— He is however not firmly master even of this— I forbear pressing too hard upon his opening intellect, and make his lessons easy— He has a writing and Russian Master twice a Week— I usually spend with him two hours every morning after Breakfast— The rest of the day untill five in the afternoon, when we dine, I receive or pay visits— Read, or write letters; arrange and settle my domestic Accounts, sometimes ride out in the sleigh with Charles, and sometimes take a short walk— It is the time for the business of the day. We sit an hour or an hour and a half at dinner— After which I walk an hour— Then read or give the time to Charles untill 9.— Between 9 and 10 I retire to Bed— The rest of the family take two or three hours more of Evening, and make of course a later Morning.
